questions.question: He fought ....................... a lion.
questions.description: As is a conjunction. It should be followed by a clause. Like is a preposition. It is followed by a noun or noun phrase which serves as its object.

questions.question: She looks a bit ........................ Princess Diana.
questions.description: As is a conjunction. It should be followed by a clause. Like is a preposition. It is followed by a noun or noun phrase which serves as its object.

questions.question: You look exactly ........................ your mother did when she was younger.
questions.description: Like is also possible here in an informal style. However, it is considered incorrect in a formal style.

questions.question: On Tuesday, ...................... on Friday, the meeting will start at
questions.description: We use 'as' before a clause and before an expression beginning with a preposition.

questions.question: I am sending you the bill, ........................ we agreed.
questions.description: As is a conjunction. It should be followed by a clause. Like is a preposition. It is followed by a noun or noun phrase which serves as its object.

questions.question: She is good at scientific subjects ......................... mathematics.
questions.description: As is a conjunction. It should be followed by a clause. Like is a preposition. It is followed by a noun or noun phrase which serves as its object.

questions.question: He was an atheist, .................................. were most of his friends.
questions.description: In a very formal style, 'as' can be followed by auxiliary verb + subject.

questions.question: Please don't use your nail ......................... a screwdriver.
questions.description: 'As' can be used to say what function or a role a person or thing has.

questions.question: A butterfly starts life ......................... a caterpillar.
questions.description: We use 'as' to say what category a person or thing belong to.

questions.question: In 1939, ..................... in 1914, everyone wanted war.
questions.description: Before a prepositional phrase, we use 'as'.

questions.question: ......................... you know, next Monday's meeting has been cancelled.
